qas.question: Who is responsible for day-to-day FBI operations?
What acts were passed relating to the FBI after 9/11?

answers.text: Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act

qas.question: Who used to brief the President?
Who now reports to the President?
Who makes sure CIA field offices are manned with qualified agents?

plausible_answers.text: Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act

qas.question: What act was passed before September 11th?
Who does the President report to?
Who is responsible for briefing the FBI director?

plausible_answers.text: any issues that arise from within the FBI

qas.question: What does the CIA director brief the President on?

context: <a0_0>The <b5_0>FBI director<b5_0/><a0_0/> is responsible for the day-to-day operations at the FBI. Along with <a1_0>his deputies<a1_0/>, the director makes sure cases and operations are handled correctly. The director also is in charge of making sure the leadership in any one of the FBI field offices is manned with qualified agents. Before the <a2_0><b6_0>Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act<b6_0/><a2_0/> was passed in the wake of the September 11 attacks, the <a3_0>FBI director<a3_0/> would directly brief the <b8_0>President of the United States<b8_0/> on <b9_0>any issues that arise from within the FBI<b9_0/>. Since then, the director now reports to the <a4_0><b7_0>Director of National Intelligence<b7_0/><a4_0/> (DNI), who in turn reports to the President.
